value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">When the <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-duno" key="Norfolk, Duchess of">duchess of Norfolk</rs>, the wife of <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-easu" key="Surrey, Earl of">Lord Surrey</rs> <del>who</del> the poet</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">who was executed <del>comes to the surface</del> <add place="above">writes</add>, she writes:</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Only in some extremity of passion or of need do they <del>come to</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">take up the pen. <del>She</del> The sound of the Bible is in</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">their ears. <del>As if</del> It is a garment only to be put on when the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">being is in <del>an attitude</del> a certain attitude.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">And the garment may of course conceal a <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-abac" key="Bacon, Anne">Lady Ann</rs></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">who is merry, who is, normally, <del>occupied with</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>happy</del> amused, or charming, or – we cannot tell</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">what real woman lives in the other side of that</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">wall of words.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Using the prose of the Bible then, the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Elizabethans are shut off from us. They can say</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">nothing subtle, nothing little. Bright contrasted</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">colours meet on their faces: carnation & snow, ebony &</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">gold. <del>Stitched into their doublets,</del> <del>the young men look</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Young men's bodies <del>look</del> are stiffly sewn into padded</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">doublets, school boys faces are raised above</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">starched collars & young women serve only to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">display heavy [guiled?] robes [strewn?] about with</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">huge pearls.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">....</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>But the writ</del></l>

<del xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <l>The separation of the writer from the audience–</l>
            <l><del>was</del> the creation of a <add place="above">an art of</add> writing, <del>profession art</del></l>
            <l>seems to have been slow</l>
            <l><del>When the</del> <del>the</del> <del>writer</del></l>
            <l><del>The writer</del> <del>The speaking voice</del> <del>When the</del></l>
            <l>the <del>speaking voice is concealed with the writing voice</del></l>
            <l>If familiar letters are written in biblical English,</l>
            <l><del>the writer cannot be</del> then the writer</l>
